w:r.w:t: Example: Description of particularly key or complex implementation of a user story
This document describes the high level design of <the product or product set>, including recording the software, technical standards and design patterns adopted and all
<Delete the following if there are no such dependencies>
Describes interfaces, interactions and inter-dependencies with other systems.
<Delete the following if there are no such areas of sp
Dips into more detail on particularly “thorny” areas of the design.

The audience for this document will primarily be those seeking a broad technical overview of the product, such as developers new to working on the product or architects or other developers seeking to integrate with the product
to re-use the product in whole
in part, or even just as an exemplar, or seeking to replace the product.

The document may also serve as a “bridge” helping to explain to architects or business analysts respectively how their architectural concepts and requirements/user stories/use cases are being implemented in practice.
For particularly complex areas of the application, the document may even serve as an aide memoir to the current developers working on the product.
The document must describe any interfaces, interactions or inter-dependencies with other systems, so that how
fits into the “big picture” of an “ecosystem” of applications is entirely clear. Such knowledge can often be critical for analysing the impacts of proposed changes or for operational support.
It is likely to include diagrams, often in Universal Modelling Language, such as realisations of any significant user stories or use cases.
It may dip into more detail on particularly “thorny” areas of the design.
Unless otherwise stated in the directions below no
and all sections should be filled in, however briefly

It is acceptable to give a more specific name to any section, but again please do so without compromising the ability of a reader already familiar with other application architectures to find material in this document, and please do not change the meaning of what the section is intended to contain. For example, if the team working on the product

use cases instead of user stories then renaming the section “Significant User Story Realisations” to “Significant Use Case Realisations” would be absolutely fine, provided that this is still the section of the document where any specific bits of design are recorded.

This document is likely to be shared with other teams whose understanding and trust of the content of the document may well be enhanced if it retains a standard structure. Unless otherwise stated in the sections below, therefore please do not add new sections unless it is absolutely unavoidable. If you do add new sections, please consider adding appendices or, failing that, adding new sections to the end of the document rather than part-way through the standard content.
in the sections that is in bold.
Please replace any text within the sections that isn’t in bold with your own text. That text is intended purely for your guidance.
I.e. specifically describe the product or closely related set of products to which this Application Architecture applies, being clear about system boundaries.
I.e. to which version of the Product/s does this Application Architecture apply?
List any documents to which this Application Architecture refers:
Another example doc, at location whatever.
I.e. a brief description (sentence or two/short paragraph) describing what the product/s do, what they are for, what is the purpose of all of this?
I.e. how any changes to this document should be authorised and where and how it should be published.
I.e. all the general underpinnings of the application, from third party software used by the product to
followed. Ideally most or even all of the content of this section ought to be merely a fleshing

specific detail of information already provided by the product’s Solution Architect in a Solution Architecture document. Filling out this section is therefore an important step towards ensuring that the Solution Architecture is sound and defining how it will be implemented.

I.e. major items of third party software used, e.g. Java or Node, databases and database versions, authentication providers (e.g. Active Directory), web servers, supported versions of HTML or CSS, supported character sets (e.g. UTF-8), application frameworks (e.g. Spring, AngularJS). The preceding list is not meant to be exhaustive. Include relevant version information so that the potential major dependencies of the product are clear.
I.e. what end-user devices, operating systems and browsers are you aiming to support?

I.e. design patterns followed and overall approach, e.g. Model-view-controller, thin client, fat client, downloadable app etc… Include a diagram here if it will help, e.g. to show the basic structure or “layering” of a product.
I.e. standards adopted, e.g. for code style, automated test
, continuous integration, version control, accessibility and security. Include the versions of those standards in case those standards are changed after adoption by this product.

I.e. functional aspects of the product or product set that apply widely or even universally across the product or product set. Again, ideally most or even all of the content of this section ought to be merely a fleshing

specific detail of information already provided by the product’s Solution Architect in a Solution Architecture document. Filling out this section is therefore an important step towards ensuring that the Solution Architecture is sound and defining how it will be implemented.

You are recommended to fill in all the sections, even if that amounts to only a sentence explaining why the section is not currently relevant. Removing a section that is not all relevant is not forbidden but should be done with great care, as design considerations that are not relevant now could be in the future, e.g. if there are changes to the sensitivity of the data handled by the product or product set, or even if say a purely “backend” service later acquires some form of administrative User Interface. Retaining those sections improves the chances that, when this document is revisited to add the new product features, the appropriate questions are triggered that identify any potential issues as soon as possible.
E.g. what are the performance constraints on this
How many users has it got? How many concurrent users? Are there any
long transactions or processes? Any obvious bottlenecks? How are these performances challenges going to be met?

I.e. what application logging and instrumentation needs to be included to ensure the running of the product or product set can be easily monitored, and to facilitate the efficient resolution of any problems? NB As a lot of troubleshooting can be needed while a product is first being built, or may need to
(for example in the case of logging)
, it can be advisable to put some such mechanisms in place as soon as possible.

I.e. how will errors be reported and information associated with errors captured for use by technical staff in resolving problems? What centralised error handling mechanisms or components will be implemented? What different approaches to error handling will be needed in different parts or layers of the system? What error information should users see? How can whatever the users see be related to potentially more detailed technical information about the error captured elsewhere (e.g. is there are some type of “cross reference”)? Remember that the purpose of error handling is not to suppress error reporting but to facilitate the identification and resolution of errors, so no error information (even if not shown to the user) should be lost or thrown away. Also note, that as many errors will occur during actual system development, putting these
in place early both provides for a thorough test of the error handling itself and can speed up and improve the quality of the development by allowing errors to be addressed more quickly.

E.g. how will data be stored? How will the data stores be accessed? How much data is there? Is there any need to cache data anywhere, for example for performance reasons or because the product or product set needs to be able to still save data even when it temporarily has no access to the main data store, and, if so, how will that caching work? How will the integrity of data writes be preserved
how will transactions be managed, and, if it is applicable, how is integrity being maintained across any distributed data? How is the referential integrity of the data being preserved
for example, if you are using a RDBMS
but retaining soft deleted data in tables, simply relying on database constraints to preserve referential integrity
? When and how will data be validated, and can data validation be centralised or compartmentalised in any way to avoid having to repeat validation logic in different parts or layers of the system?

I.e. how much contention could there be for the data? If so will the chosen data access mechanisms cope, and what locking strategy or strategies will be used if multiple users could attempt to change the same item of data at the same time?
E.g. is any personal data included? What is the protective marking of the data? How will data be protected?
data be retained? How will data that must be removed be identified and deleted?
Where more detail will be provided in the “Audit” or “User Access and Security” sections, refer to those sections rather than repeat the information here.

E.g. will data history be kept? Will deletes be “hard” or soft in some way? Are we going to record which users change data items, and how, or even which users access which data items? Who can see the audit and how? How will these principles be implemented?

E.g. do you need to secure access to the system to certain users? Are all users the same, i.e. able to access the same data and perform the same functions, or should different users receive different system authorisations? What authentication and authorisation services do you intend to use? How will system or data access dependent on different types or levels of user authorisation be implemented? How can you be as certain as you need to be that your users are who they say they are? (Most likely not an issue if you are using internal users maintained through a common access and authentication service, but not so straight forward if, say, you are opening your system to external users in any way, and there would be any advantage to anyone pretending to be someone else). Should any data be stored encrypted, and, if so how? Should traffic into or out of the product or product set be encrypted, and, if so, how (e.g. Transport Layer Security)? Will any interactions with external systems need to be secured and, if so, how?
I.e. with what resources or other systems will the product have to connect, and how? Will any of the product
have to work offline, with no connection to any server resources and
will they cache data, and if so how? Any other bottlenecks or potential interruptions that need to be considered and worked around?
If the product is divided into a number of components, or we are talking here about a set of inter-connecting products that is each a component, how will they talk to each other?
Note that this section is about the general approaches (

JSON calls to RESTful interfaces) and technologies used (such as protocols, e.g. HTTPS). Any detail that would be better placed in other sections, such as “Interaction with External Systems”, should not be repeated here.
I.e. how configurable does the system need to be and how will that configurability be implemented?

Consider what should be configured, by whom, how and when (e.g. during the creation of a new release, by “back-end" changes after a release, or through a user interface during live running). NB where configurability changes in any way the rules applying to data, consider what that might mean for data that has already been created.
How will the product or product set, and especially any user interfaces, ensure appropriate access to differently abled users, for example, to the visually impaired?

I.e. how will we stamp the product or product set with a version and/or build labels? How will version and are or build details be viewable? (NB often there will be no meaningful distinction between the

of “version” or “build”. However, if a product comprises of a number of components, which can potentially change independently, then the product version may need to change any time any of the component builds change, even though some of the component builds may stay the same.) Note that version and build information can be essential in protecting against configuration management issues, for example in ensuring that the current versions and builds have been deployed, and for troubleshooting, for example for ensuring that the correct version or build is investigated when

E.g. multi-language support or special high availability concerns, if applicable. Where such considerations are numerous and/or significant, feel free to replace this section with additional sections of your own.
I.e. a “big picture” of the product/s, describing and/or showing its major parts and how they interact. Where some components provide “common services” to ma
y parts of the product or product set, and so are
critical, make this clear. A diagram, such as a UML Component Diagram, will often be especially useful here.
I.e. is the product or product set intended to offer any form of re-usable service to other products? If so describe those

services here, including either a full API definition or a reference to full API definition held somewhere else, so that other software engineers will know what to build if they want to interact with this product. The audience for this section is primarily other technical staff who might want to make use of this product or product set.
If no re-usable services are provided this section may be deleted.

product or product set interacts with external systems, both as a consumer of data or services and as a provider of data or services. A diagram, such as a UML Component Diagram, will usually be especially useful here.
Also include here the full API

of any interfaces exposed to external systems, or a reference to that API definition if held somewhere else, unless this information has already been provided in the “Re-usable Services” section. Sufficient information should be provided so that other software engineers will know what they need to build and maintain to carry on interacting with this product or product set.
If there is no interaction with external systems this section may be deleted.
If this product or product set stores data in any form include either

of the underlying data model here or a reference to a description held somewhere else, such as in the Solution Architecture if the model is simple, or in a full data model held somewhere else if it is complex.
If there is no such data storage this section may be deleted.
Example: Description of particularly key or complex implementation of a user story

I.e. detailed design: but only for those parts or aspects of an application that really justify it. Detailed program specifications are usually pointless: they often do not even survive initial attempts at coding up a solution, as then the coder will either realise that the specification is wrong, or that there is a better way to solve the stated problem. Such specifications are rarely ever read again and, unless continually laboriously updated, soon drift into becoming out of date. Detailed program specifications have also been rendered less useful by techniques such as user stories with clear and comprehensive acceptance criteria, test driven development, any of the forms of “

” or prototyping and by an application architecture document that clearly describes the full technical context of every individual part of the product, such as how data should be persisted or how errors should be handled.

To get an idea of what should be included in this section consider the following: if an implementation is so tricky that a developer had to prepare anything beyond a sketchy design before commencing coding then include that design here. Additionally, if any part of the product is sufficiently complex and/or critical that other developers are likely to need more explanation than can reasonably be gathered by reading the code and comments, then also include some design here.

xsd:annotation.xsd:documentation: This value indicates the number of saves or revisions. The application is responsible for updating this value after each revision.
